{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3411625,"name":"","username":"Striker-909","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/striker-909/{size}/230788_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-27T20:06:28.998Z","cooked":"

Our summer coding project was to try to use the the openftc library to use apriltags to place ourselves on the field. However, while we can successfully identify apriltags using a properly calibrated Logitech Carl Zeiss Tessar HD 1080p camera, the pose data we are retrieving from those detections is inconsistent and inaccurate.

The pose data has 6 measurements, x, y, z, yaw, pitch, roll. Y is the only measurement that seems to work as intended, giving us the distance from the camera to the wall with the apriltag, perpendicular with the wall.

We expected that the x position would be similar, the parallel distance from the camera to the center of the apriltag but the the X values returned were wildly off. We haven’t done anything with the Z measurement as the camera will stay at a fixed height on the robot.

The angles at first seemed work as expected. We were only working with yaw as we only care about the XY plane, as stated before. We expected that the angles would be the angle between a line shooting straight out of the camera and one shooting straight out from the center of the apriltag, perpendicular to the wall.

However, we started to notice sever jumping at certain angles. The yaw would jump back and forth even when the camera was not being touched. This made any data we got from the camera extremely unreliable as we needed to use trigonometry to determine the X value (As the pose.x was wildly inaccurate as stated before).

Additionally, the angles don’t seem to be centered around a line perpendicular to the aprilrag, an angle from one side of the apriltag would read 9 degrees while its mirror would read -56 degrees.

If anyone has any insight into how either the pose.x measurement or angle work or are measured/used, it would be greatly appreciated. If any of my wording was unclear I will try to explain to the best of my ability.

Hi! I haven’t heard of any successful use case of April tag navigation with the OpenFTC. Still, the official FTC SDK provided an April-tag navigation API and a drive-to-apriltag example.
By the way, pure vision odometry is unstable, you should have a dead-wheel odometry first and implement a Karman filter. I recommend using the WPILib position estimator. You can see how we migrated the WPI-math library to FTC here, you would have to change some JDK11+ syntax to JDK8 syntax. And you’ll also need this custom PoseEstimator class for the FTC dead-wheels odometry. This way you can combine your dead-wheel odometry and the vision odometry.
